• Introduction
  • 1. Identifying able-bodied/ neurotypical privilege
  • 2. An introduction to "epistemic violence"
  • 3. Organizing an inclusive event for persons with disabilities
  • 4. Designing outreach programs for ethnic minorities and indigenous people
  • 5. Making events safe and welcoming
  • 6. Reading List

Reading List

Written by : Shobha S V
Edited and Reviewed by : Chinmayi S K

Issues like sexuality, gender, disability, caste etc. have a huge impact on how knowledge is created and consumed by all of us. It is said that knowledge is power and it is indeed true. These readings are an attempt at understanding how these factors disempower people in different ways and how, as people of privilege, we can be sensitive towards their reality and use our privilege to help them.

Gender and Sexuality

The everyday feminism piece is about how to address the trans community while writing about them online. It is a useful piece, especially when we write biographies about trans people on Wikipedia.

5 Ways Using Correct Gender Pronouns Will Make You a Better Trans* Ally - Everyday Feminism, Laura Kacere (September 23, 2013), Retrieved February 15, 2019 https://everydayfeminism.com/2013/09/correct-gender-pronouns-to-be-trans-ally/

Here is a beginners glossary for the various words that can get you started in being an ally to the LGBTQIA community Equality Literacy 101. (n.d.) Retrieved February 15, 2019, from https://bolt.straightforequality.org/files/Come%20Out%20as%20a%20Straight%20Ally/equality-li teracy-101-s4e-.pdf

Nadika's piece about her journey of dating as a trans woman is an incredibly touching piece of finding herself and finding love.

Nadika Nadja. (2015) 'The smartphone freed me': a journey of dating as a transwoman. Retrieved February 15, 2019, https://deepdives.in/the-smartphone-freed-me-a-journey-of-dating-as-a-transwoman-884cd2b 78 6fa

When platforms are not inclusive, people from marginalised communities find difficult to use them. It also, often puts them at risk. This piece speaks about a specific genre of apps which are related to dating and how they are of disservice to them.

Smita Vanniyar. (2017) 'How Queer are your Dating Apps'?. Retrieved February 15, 2019, http://www.tarshi.net/inplainspeak/how-queer-are-your-dating-apps/

When we think of sexuality, asexuality is hardly discussed. The final piece in this section is a beautiful insight into the asexuality networks in India. Shreya Ila Anasuya. (2017) 'There's someone else just like you': inside India's asexuality networks. Retrieved February 15, 2019, https://deepdives.in/theres-someone-else-just-like-you-inside-india-s-asexuality-networks-e6e 7b 74f5063

Caste

Reading about lived experiences of people who have faced caste discrimination all their lives simply for belonging to a certain caste is essential for a lot of us will never understand what it is to walk in their shoes. This piece by Tejas Harad is a great example on how the multiple axes of privilege acts out in one's life.

Tejas Harad. (2017) How Privilege Actually Works (No, It's Not About Scoring Points On A Quiz). Retrieved February 15, 2019, https://www.buzzfeed.com/tejasharad/how-privilege-actually-works-no-its-not-about-scoring

Discussions about caste, especially online usually end up in heated debates with things getting personal quite often. Yashica Dutt's article lends an insight on how someone with privilege can one discuss about caste in a meaningful way. Yashica Dutt. (2016) The Non-Dalit's Guide To Debating Meaningfully About Caste | HuffPost India. Retrieved February 15, 2019, https://www.huffingtonpost.in/yashica-dutt-/so-you-want-to-meaningful_b_9129308.html

While one may also think that caste is a reality of Indian subcontinent, it is also a reality check for us to know how caste transcends continents too. The piece by Thenmozhi Soundarrajan reflects on this issue. It also throws light into how someone from upper caste can discuss caste and caste oppression in a sensitive way. Thenmozhi Soundararajan and Sinthujan Varatharajah. (2015) Caste Privilege 101: A Primer for the Privileged - The Aerogram. Retrieved February 15, 2019, http://theaerogram.com/caste-privilege-101-primer-privileged/

The piece by Christina Dhanaraj is an eye-opener about the realities of being a Dalit person in corporate India. Christina Thomas Dhanaraj. (2017) What it Means to be a Dalit Woman in Corporate India|The Ladies Finger. Retrieved February 15, 2019, http://theladiesfinger.com/dalit-woman-corporate-india/

Tejas Harad. (2018) A Guide To Fighting Daily Casteism Around You. Retrieved February 15, https://www.buzzfeed.com/tejasharad/a-guide-to-fighting-daily-casteism-around-you

The last piece is a highly engaging comic about caste realities in India. Sumit Kumar. (2014) Dalit Lalit - Bakarmax. Retrieved February 15, 2019 https://bakarmax.com/comic/dalit-lalit/

Disability

Elizabeth Rust. (2015) How the internet still fails disabled people | Technology | The Guardian. Retrieved February 15, 2019 ,https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/jun/29/disabled-people-internet-extra-costs-co m mission-scope
